name: Wall Sit of Doom
description: A single scene is established. One player will always not be in the scene -- This player will be doing a wall sit on the side until someone from the scene makes up an excuse and leaves the scene. The player who left will take the place of the person wall sitting. This game continues until the wall sitter falls

name: Follow The Leaver
description: Normal scenes will take place. At some point either person in the scene will try to leave. Whoever leaves, we will follow them and start a new scene in the new location. Continue following the person who leaves the scene.
example: Someone is at the grocery store checkout buying food and weird stuff happens. The checker gets offended and storms off. We then see the next scene taking place in the store breakroom where the checker is trying to cool off...

name: One Line Fanfic
description: The MC will get a suggestion of two wildly different characters/people. The backline will then begin to create a fan fiction of the two suggestions by going down the line and each contributing a sentence to this new story. Play continues until the story reaches a conclusion. It can repeat back to the start of the backline. Look for a way that the story is able to resolve in some way. Around 12 lines will be for a good story, but that's just a recommendation
example: JarJarBinks x Joe Biden: Player A) 'Joe... you're injured', said JarJar as he embraced Joe. Player B) 'JJ, Darth Vader has found us, we have to leave.' Player C) The sweat glistened on JarJar's brow as he took out a lightsaber - 'We aren't leaving here without a fight'...

name: Acronyms
description: One person says a word (preferably shorter), and everyone will take turns explaining what that word actually means by associating each letter with a word. Once the word has been defined everyone will repeat the Word and what each letter stands for together.
example: 'Duck' is the word suggested. Player A) disguised, Player B) underlings, Player C) creating  Player D) keyboards. Everyone) 'Duck - Disguised Underlings Creating Keyboards'

name: Fortune Cookie
description: You are creating some fortune cookie wisdom, one word at a time. Each player takes turn adding a word to the fortune. If someone feels that the fortune is complete they do little claps and say 'yes yes yes'.
example: Each player adds a word something like this - 'if. you. find. yourself. in. a. portapotty. with. no. escape. remember. down. is. not. an. escape.  'yesyesyes'

name: Favorite Character
description: Think of a favorite childhood character. Then imagine a new character that you draw with all the skills of your 8 year old self. Think of what makes them special. Image all the colors and shapes.

name: Character Breathing
description: Everyone closes their eyes. Imagine a certain character (archetype, emotion, attitude, etc). Begin to breathe how that person might breathe. As you go through this exercise, begin to hold yourself how this person may hold themselves.
example: If I was imagining an old cowboy. I may take deep, heavy breaths. My brow may be furrowed from all the hard times I’ve spent on the range. I may be hunched over a bit from all the hard work I’ve done.

name: Dictionary
description: Person A will make up a nonsensical word. Person B will give a definitive definition of Person’s A word.
example: A: 'FlimFlam' B: 'FlimFlam. Noun. The stuff that sticks to the top of the tinfoil of a yogurt container.'

name: Mind Meld
description: All players get in a circle. The goal is for A and B to say the same word.  A and B will count down from 3 and then say a random word. If it is the same word – great! If not, B and C become a new pair. Continue around the circle trying to find a connection between the last pair of words.
example: A says 'Tacos' and B says 'Weekend.' B says 'Tuesday' and C says 'Party.' C and D both say 'FRIDAY!'

name: Who Who Where What Why Why (6 W's)
description: Split into two lines, A says who they are. B says who they are. A says where they are at. B says what they’re both doing. A says how they feel. B says how they feel. Good exercise for writing and setting up a scene quickly.
example:
A: 'I am a dragon.' 
B: 'I am a knight.' 
A: 'We are at a drive-in movie theater' 
B: 'We are sharing popcorn and our hands touch.' 
A: 'I feel bashful, will a dragon and a knight work?' 
B: 'I feel excited, this is my big shot!'

name: Gift Exchange
description: Similar to Questions Only, except with giving gifts. Gifts could include giving the other character a name, a detail or personality trait, a piece of backstory, etc. Try to give a gift with every line. Use a location for a prompt. Encourage the players to do scenes about characters who already know each other.
example:
A: 'Hey there Frank, thanks for coming with me to your favorite restaurant, Jersey Mike’s' 
B: 'No prob, Bob. I'm just grateful you could get out of sword fencing to do this.' 
A: 'Anything for you Frank. You're such a great friend, you're always letting people borrow your big truck.' 
B: 'That's right, you always need it for your lumberjack job, so I'm happy to help.' 
A: 'And you bring it to me even though you hate the outdoors! That's real friendship.'

name: Revolver
description: 4 players, A, B, C & D, stand in a circle, with two (A and B) in front. The host gives them a prompt, then says 'Rotate' and everyone rotates clockwise. This set of two actors (B and C) is given a prompt, and so on (C and D, D and A) until you have four prompts for four separate scenes. Then, after a quick review of everyone’s prompts, the first set of actors, A and B, begins a scene. After a short time, the host calls 'Rotate,' and we rotate to see the next pair’s scene (B and C).

name: Ghost Court
description: Think of a show where people sue each other, like Judge Judy. The Judge will get a prompt/genre for what the type of court will be: Ghost, Fantasy RPG, Spy, Plumber, etc… Once the prompt is received, the Judge will introduce the Plaintiff. The Plaintiff states their case against the Defendant. The Defendant states why they are innocent, and the Judge asks a few follow up questions, then declares whether the Plaintiff wins or if the case is being thrown out. Tip: instead of saying 'no, that didn't happen,' say things like 'that may be true, but the only reason I'm haunting this house is because it's been in my house for generations!'

name: Number of Words
description: The Host gives each player a specific number of words. 1-10 work best, but for a fun, spicy challenge you can throw out an absurd number like 30. The Players perform a scene, but every line they speak must contain exactly the amount of words that they've been given. Periodically, the Host can pause the game and change each player’s number of words.

name: 4 ways to die
description: Get 4 suggestions from the audience on different ways to die ranging from realistic to absurd. Players try to work a way into

name: A to B
description: players take turns saying the first thing that comes to their mind when hearing the previous player’s word. Go around the circle for 2 to 4 full rotations
example: A) Dog, B) Treat, C) Icecream, D) Cold, A) Winter, etc…,

name: A to C
description: Alternate to ‘A to B’, players take turns saying the second association from hearing the previous player’s word.  Go around the circle for 2 to 4 full rotations
example: If someone says ‘Tree’, the first thing in mind would be bark, and bark would make you think of dogs, so you say dog.,

name: Alphabet Game
description: Starting with any letter, players begin each line with the next sequential letter in the alphabet. Continue until you get back to the beginning letter.
example: ’Aliens are here!’, ‘Bet they’re here for our tatertots’, ‘Can’t believe we’ll be tater-less,

name: Answering Machine
description: Players take turns leaving a message on an answering machine for a character that they’re creating. Paint the actions of this mysterious person by showing the effects of their actions. Continue increasing the absurdity.
example: Someone leaves a message for Mr. Rogers saying ‘Hey Mr Rogers, your tank is still parked in my front yard. Are you going to come get it?’,

name: Categories
description: One player picks a topic and everyone will then go around adding things that fit into the topic
example: Fast Food Items - Tacos, Burgers, Fries, Frosty,

name: Don’t think about it
description: Similar to A-C, one player will start with any word. Players will go around the circle and try to say something that is NOT related to the previous word. This activity helps us to see that everything can be related in some way. Our minds are better at connections than we thing

name: Fortunately Unfortunately
description: The two players who are the narrators produce a story together. One role is ‘Fortunately’ and the other is ‘Unfortunately’. ‘Fortunately will give us an optimistic twist on the current situation. ‘Unfortunately’ gives a pessimistic twist. Each narrator will keep taking turns putting their twist on each other’s response. Make sure to keep progressing the story with each challenge/resolution and don’t get stuck in a loop trying to shut down the other person. Each narrator begins with ‘Fortunately/Unfortunately’
example: Fortunately, Jared just won the lottery. Unfortunately, the mafia was here to get their cut. Fortunately, Jared had prepared for this and threw out his makeshift rope and descended his apartment building. etc…,

name: Mumble Murder Mystery
description: 2 players will leave. The MC will get suggestions for a person, place, and how they died. One of the players who have left will return. The player who knows the information will then begin to pantomime. Players cannot use words, but they can mumble. Once the player guessing thinks they’ve figured out the three different aspects of the murder, they themselves kill the other person. Repeat this with the last player. Once the game is finished have the players repeat back what they thought each aspect was.

name: Objection!/Experts
description: An MC will get a suggestion from the audience for what is the expertise of our experts. One player will step out and begin monologuing about the topic. At any time a backline player may call out ‘objection!’ and give a reason why what the current expert was saying was wrong. The MC will either sustain or overrule the objection.
